												Ed Mcmillen is, arguably, a video game auteur (though, no one would really contest that). If he isn't an auteur yet, he certainly is a recognizable personality and a welcome individual to the world of video games.The Basement Collection is a bundle of Mcmillen's flash work prior to his big hits ("Super How the Hell Did I Miscalculate That?" and "The Binding of Why The Hell Can't I Stop Playing?"). So, the big question is, do the games hold up?Well like any art or artist, it takes time to develop skill and hone one's-oh wait, nevermind these games are gold. Honestly, you would think that at some point Mcmillen and his team screwed up and made an awful game somewhere and had to bury it like a dirty secret.None of these games are some crayon drawing that a parent puts on the fridge to make themselves or their children feel better. The games included in this compilation are all fascinating and top notch, and all of them feel very different from one another. These games all share the familar Team Meat aesthetic and challenge. Out of the games here there should definitely be at least one that will warrant a purchase from you. Maybe it will be the somber story of the adventure game Aether? Or maybe the frantic Grey Matter? Maybe Time ♥♥♥♥, the perplexing puzzle platformer with a dark twist? If you can't find one game here to enjoy, there honestly might be nothing that pleases you.

  TL;DR  : An amazing set of original indie flash games, each single one has something great about it. Amazing gameplays, great music, some original stories, a great art style... A must have if you're into simple and quick indie games, and if you like other Edmund McMillen's games. Definitely worth its price. The Basement Collection is a collection of different indie flash games, created mostly by the creators of Super Meat Boy / The Binding of Isaac.Story / SettingMost of what the games have to offer is their gameplay and art style, but some of these games have a really unique story. Meat Boy and Spewer barely even have one for example, whereas Coil is really story driven, even if its story is not really clear, and it requieres your own interpretation of the game. Time ♥♥♥♥ and Aether's stories are present and interesting, but really aren't the core of the games. Finaly, if you unlock AVGM, I'd say that its the game that has the most meaning in the list, this game is litteraly a parody of other games and is only worth playing if you understand what the games is making fun of (or if you want the achievements !) GameplayTrust me, there's going to be at least one game that you'll enjoy playing in there. Most of the games are hard to beat completely, like, really hard. Even if you reach the "end" of the game, there's going to be advanced levels or achievements that will take a while to beat and obtain. I guess you already know how Meat Boy works, since it's basically the original version of Super Meat Boy (one of the best and most challenging platformer I know of). Spewer is an amazing platformer as well, but requieres a bit more tactics than Meat Boy. Aether is like... the smallest sandbox game I've played, it's fun to play and really is different from all these really hard games. I didn't play Triachnid much but it's gameplay is quite unique, even if I found it a bit boring after a while. Grey-Matter is like one of these old Starship arcade games, it's hard to describe. It was fun but I'm a noob at it :( Time ♥♥♥♥ was my favorite one to play and has an awesome idea behind it. It requieres a lot of attention and reactivity, especially in the harder levels. I'd say that it's half puzzle, half platformer, it reminded me of Fez in a way. The only problem with it was the saving system, make sure you click "exit" on the right, under the person who speaks to you (no spoiler) so that the game saves your progress, and try to quit the game with the in game option (top left). PerformanceKnowing it's a flash game... the performance was pretty bad for what the games had to offer, but it was totally playable. I did have to lower my screen resolution to play Spewer and Aether properly, as the games were quite laggy (kinda like the first Binding of Isaac was, for me). The game can't be rendered by my GPU (because it's flash I guess ?!) and uses integrated intel graphics :( Probably won't be an issue if you have a desktop PC with more a more recent CPU. Style / Graphics As always with Ed, i'm not dissapointed. It's not as full of weird wonderful things as The binding of Isaac, but pretty much each game has it's own look and feel. Triachnid and Aether were especially enjoyable to play simply because of their art style. Time ♥♥♥♥ wasn't especially nice visualy, (I know that the pixelated look was what was desired) but the game clearly isn't about it's graphics. Finally, the music. Wow. Danny Baranowsky is by far my favorite video game soundtrack composer. If after playing Time ♥♥♥♥, Meat Boy and AVGM, you don't have the melodies stuck in your head you must be deaf.

 The Basement Collection. What can I say about this game? ▼ ▼ ▼  The Basement Collection is a collection of award winning games released in years around 2006-2009, all of which have won many awards and have been nominated. Once you finish the base game of a game in the Basement Collection, you unlock an extra that may or may not be related to the game you beat at all. The extras usually contain artwork or a comic, but beating two of the games, (I wont say which) grants you two unlockable games. Do note though that these are the 2 only unlockable games in The Basement Colleciton. Every single game in The Basement Collection is amazing and unique in it's own way. There are 6 base games to start with, and 2 unlockable games, making for a total of 8 games. The starting games are Aether, Time ♥♥♥♥, Spewer, Meat Boy, Coil, and Triachnid. The unlockable games are   AVGM & Grey Matter.  Pros:- Every game is amazing and REALLY fun, REALLY well designed and are all challenging!- Great soundtrack for each game and the main menu's!- Great list of achievements!- Each game has unique puzzle gameplay which you must think about carefully and put into action before finishing the levels.- Each completed game unlocks and extra containing a comic, concept art, or an unlockable game!- Super cheap! $4.99!Cons:- The Basement Collection runs in flash, which means all the games in the collection are going to run in flash. This sometimes results in lag, deaths because of lag, a random crash I had once due to flash, and the game Spewer can be REALLY laggy if a lot of puke is on the screen, and I have an Intel i7 and Nvidia 1080.- Sometimes, but not always, and very rarely, random crashes when I go into SHIFT + TAB (Most likely due to flash but not 100% sure), but nothing to be worried about it imo.FINAL VERDICT:9/10 - Excellent!

												TL;DR Below.Like many other people say: You need to be a fan of Edmund in order to fully enjoy this collection. I myself had no idea who he was until I played this collection and his story is truly fascinating. I really do recommend people to go and hear his story because I'm sure many people can relate to him on different levels. Despite that, the majority of games were not my cup of tea but that doesn't necessarily mean they're horrible.I absolutely love Super Meat Boy and was amazed to find the original in the collection. Aether was also another interesting game I thoroughly enjoyed. Every other part of the collection was "meh" and I found it to be quite boring if not too frustrating to fully enjoy. Another problem I had was the frames. All games of the collection require little graphical demand to run and I have a top of the line CPU and GPU but still found games running at a frame rate as low as 10. This obstacle makes some games almost impossible to play as they require some complex platforming. The reasoning I believe is because they're made in flash and are in fact flash games. These are the infancy stages of what he's created and since they are flash games, you can easily find and play them elsewhere with better performance than on this, with no cost. That being said, you are in technicality paying for behind the scenes.Regardless of the problems I had, The Basement Collection is an interesting one at that and is one I can only recommend if you're quite fond of Edmund McMillen. The games as a game in my opinion are quite mediocre but that is because they are "flash games", but if you can connect to Edmund as well as his games then I think you would truly enjoy them. Being able to relate to Edmund can really make his games pieces of art.The collection as a whole unfortunately I cannot recommend because of it's performance issues, gameplay mediocrity, and price tag. Even though I said I recommend it to people who are fans of Edmund, and his story is fascinating, this review is geared towards the game/collection itself, not Edmund.TL;DR: You will only really enjoy the game/collection regardless of the poor performance fully if you meet very specific criteria. (Personal conflicts, Fan of Edmund McMillen, etc.) Buy at own discretion.

												Edmund McMillen is a professional troll and game designer with a perverted and vile sense of humor. He's also a genius. He's the man behind the modern classics Super Meat Boy and The Binding of Isaac, titles you should already recognize if you've been a Steam gamer for any amount of time.The Basement Collection is a compilation of his old flash games which made him famous on Newgrounds. Granted, it's an excellent compilation, complete with tons of extra levels and DVD extras, but whether it's worth your time or not really just boils down to the question "How eager are you to play these games again?"I say this, because this collection mainly exists for historical significance alone. The games themselves are low-res, glitchy, have mildly-to-maddeningly infuriating controls, and most of them are simply exercises in masochism. They’re the type of game you beat just to be able to say you beat it, and that it’s finally over with. In other words, a good challenge. But if you want to unlock all the extras that make this package worth the money, you’ve got to play through the games again. So it all comes down to how appealing that sounds to you.If these games are important to you and mean something to you, if they were the games that defined your childhood and the games you'd secretly play in computer lab in high school or something, hey, I respect that. Buy it without hesitation and support the man who gave you hours of joy in your youth. We all have our nostalgia bombs and we have every right to indulge.But if you've never played these games before, there are much better Edmund McMillen games on the market, as well as better games to play for their historical significance alone; I recommend seeking those out instead.(Oh, and it’s also quite hard to 100%, so achievement hunters beware!)

Unfortunately, those play out more like a ROM hack of this game instead of just being more levels fo play through. Those aren't really fun.Spewer is my favorite from this collection of games. It's a puzzle platformer where your character has basically a barfing jetpack mechanic to help him get to certain places. The levels are pretty fun, and the main gimmick has plenty of ways to work out. 												The Basement Collection is a pretty nice variety of games made by the talented Edmund McMillen. It collections contains a bunch of games, which can be either found online or playable in this game only.Let's start with Meat Boy. If you played Super Meat Boy before, you should know the story. Your girlfriend Bandage Girl has been kidnapped by the evil Dr. Fetus. The plot is nearly the same, and was the original plot that later appeared in Super Meat Boy.In Spewer, you play as a little creature that tries to escape the scientist's lab by spewing puke, activate traps and avoid the traps. One of my definite favorites, and requires some thinking.Time ♥♥♥♥ (that's getting an sequel soon) is another puzzle game that features Steven, a person who has no idea in what situation he has trapped himself in and tries to find himself the way out. A very strange puzzle game.Coil features a story similar to well, how a person gets made. It's been a while since i finished that one. It's pretty short, but still a fun one-time experience.In Triachnid you play as a three-legged spider called Triachnid that wants to explore and find his lost larva. I always had trouble controlling this one, but you will get the hang of it.Aether has this kid that rides his octopus-like creature and sticks onto planets and discover the 5 different moons. The game also features some hard to find easter eggs that require both exploring and playing with coordinates.And finally, Grey Matter. This plays similar to a arcade game and you have to make triangular shapes as much as you can while avoiding all kinds of stuff. Quite difficult.Each of the games feature special unlockables and other stuff when completing certain chapters or the whole game. These may vary and could be things like prototypes, videos, art and more. There's also 2 special games that can be unlocked by completing multiple games.And that's the Basement Collection. Should you get it? I think you should. If you like Edmund's work or you just like to play a bunch of games in one with special unlockables, you will most likely have fun and have some rage-inducing moments. The $4 is definitely worth the price. I just would like to say that the game runs most games in Flash, and tend to make them laggier. The menu will not have this problem.

As you go room to room and solve puzzles, this other self constantly puts you down and spouts all sorts of disturbing nonsense, while simulatenously cheering you on and pleading for help. Imagine something like an existentialist GLaDos, only crazier and more negative. If you can imagine that.The game itself raises a multitude of philosophical questions and really makes you think deeply beyond the creative puzzles. 												I have been a fan of Edmund Mcmillen ever since he was back on Newgrounds, so the second I saw a compilation of all of those games redone come on sale, I was quite excited to jump back into the fray of the physics-platformers the man is known for, especially the original Meat Boy, which is fairly nostalgic to me.Now, briefly, let me sum up the games: they're fine.They're still well designed, sometimes brilliant little games that achieve so much with so little. I enjoy Spewer's, Time ♥♥♥♥'s, Aether's new smoother, crispier selves. Meat Boy was thrown under the bus.Meat Boy is a very good game with consistent controls. These controls, while a tad floaty, are suited to the game's design. Meat Boy jumps just within the right height and width the character needs to see to the end of the level, turning this struggle into an elegant foray of taps and clicks. Every time you press the space bar, you feel in control of the hang time and brevity of the leap. It's simple and comfortable for a game with vertically designed levels in mind.Super Meat Boy's levels are, for the most part, horizontal, and designed for a controller.So, whoever decided to throw out the original controls in turn for these new ones is an idiot.Meat Boy, as a game where it's levels are designed with the controls in mind, does NOT work with new controls.Simple.Now the game plays like an awkward, floppy piece of meat, where instead of dancing across levels, now feels as entertaining as swinging a stick around in a figure 8. Also, the stick is falling apart, constantly. As SOON as you let go of the space button, Meat Boy plummets to the ground as fast as he left. There is no arch like there was in the original, just because more people played Super Meat Boy and that's what they're used to.And hey, on a controller, I'M used to that too! But guess what? No controller support!AND, you can't change the controls back to the original!MAN. I LIKE THIS REDESIGN.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												The Basement Collection is a collection (hah) of a bunch of flash games and bonus content brought to us by Edmund McMillen.  To tell you the truth, most of the games weren't very good, just your typical flash-based time wasters:Triachnid was unplayable due to the input lag on the controls,Aether is a gravity-based physics platformer with a few puzzles to complete.  The music is good and there's some strange McMillen style story going on, if you're interested in this title it's available for free online (Newgrounds).Time CFUK is a puzzle platformer that deals with alternate dimentions or time travel or something.  It's actually pretty well put-together and I'd say is the highlight of the games in the collection.  I found the strange storyline appealing.  This is available for free online as well.Spewer is a physics-based platformer where you puke out goo that you use to navigate the levels.  It's alright, your typical flash-based game.   Once again, available for free online. Meat Boy - the prequel to Super Meat Boy.  Super Meat Boy is great because of its tight controls.  Imagine if Super Meat Boy had laggy controls and no controller support - that's what playing Meat Boy is like.  If you want to see what the flash prototype for Super Meat Boy is like you can find it free online.Grey Matter is kind of like a shmup but instead of shooting you use your "ship" to smash into things, creating a triangle within which the enemies die.  I'm a big fan of shmups and found this to be lacking.  If you want to check it out, it's free online (seeing a pattern here?)Coil isn't so much a game as it is art.  It was an alright piece, I found it weird and difficult to figure out.  You might like it, I wasn't a huge fan.  Check it out for free online for the same experience. Besides the above games, you can unlock the following games:The Lonely Hermit (beat Triachnid) - never played this because Triachnid is broken.  You can find it free online.AVGM - "Abusive Video Game Manipulation (beat Coil) - a real stupid game.  All you do is click a lightswitch to make items appear and disappear.  Pretty huge waste of time.  You can find it free online.In addition to those two if you browse to [~steamapps/common/basement/moregames] there are four more games:Carious Welting - a missile defense clone with McMillin's art style.  Available free online.Carious Welting 2 - sequel to the above, same idea.  Available free online.Clubby the Seal - sidescrolling action game where you're a seal and kill Eskimos.  Available free online.Dumpling - a momentum-based physics game.  Available free online.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Besides the games you get some bonus artwork and drawings from McMillen's sketchbooks.  There's a bit more bonus content but that's really the extent of it.Would only recommend if you're a huge, HUGE fan of Edmund McMillen.  Otherwise you can pass and either play the games free online to see what they're about or just skip them entirely - most are pretty forgetable.

												As you probably know, this is an anthology of McMillen's earlier work, mostly from Newgrounds. All the games are availiable for free, but the fun extras combined with the low price, make for a very attractive purchase. Said extras include, but are not limited to: two extra games (a joke game and a map pack for meatboy), examples of McMillen's drawings (two full comics and an assortment of sketches) and expanded soundtrack for all games. Anyone who remotely enjoys McMillen's work will be familiar with at least some of the games, but all games contain bonus extras that go from early technical demos to cut footage from IGTM, going through fan Q&A in a talk-show-like format hosted by Danielle (McMillen's wife & business partner).
